However, as economies recover from recessions or when borrowing costs are low, small companies often surpass larger ones in performance. During the most severe parts of a recession, small businesses with robust cash flows frequently represent excellent value investments because analysts and institutional investors tend to penalize the whole sector of small cap stocks.

data.text: What does this statement regarding put options mean? fennec has a very good answer but i feel it provides too much information. So i'll just try to explain what that sentence says. Put option is the right to sell a stock. "16 puts on Cisco at 71 cents", means John comes to Jim and says, i'll give you 71 cent now, if you allow me to sell one share of Cisco to you at $16 at some point in the future ( on expiration date).  NYT quote says 1000 puts that means 1000 contracts - he bought a right to sell 100,000 shares of Cisco on some day at $16/share. Call option - same idea: right to buy a stock.
data.label: human

data.text: What is implied by the statement about put options? While fennec's response is quite comprehensive, I'll try to simplify it. A put option grants the holder the right to sell a stock. When we say "16 puts on Cisco at 71 cents," it means John offers Jim 71 cents now in exchange for the permission to sell one share of Cisco to him at $16 sometime in the future (on the expiration date). The New York Times quote mentions 1,000 puts, indicating that 1,000 contracts were purchased, giving him the right to sell 100,000 shares of Cisco at $16 per share on a specified day. A call option is similar but involves the right to purchase a stock instead.

The quote from The New York Times refers to purchasing 1,000 puts, meaning that 1,000 contracts were acquired, giving the holder the right to sell 100,000 shares of Cisco at $16 per share on a specified day. data.text: Will I be able to purchase land? Here are some important things to think about.  Alan and Denise Fields discuss them in more detail in Your New House. Permanent work.  Where do you want to live?  Are there suitable jobs nearby?  How much do they pay? Emergency fund.  Banks care that you have "reserves" (and/or an unsecured line of credit) in case you have a run of bad luck.  This also helps with float the large expenses when closing a loan. Personal line of credit. Who are you building for?  If you are not married, then you should consider whether building a home makes that easier, or harder.  If you hope to have kids, you should consider whether your home will make it easier to have kids, or harder.  If you are married (or seriously considering it), make sure that your spouse helps with the shopping, and is in agreement on the priorities and choices.  If you are not married, then what will you do if/when you get married?  Will you sell?  expand?  build another house on the same lot?  rent the home out? Total budget.  How much can the lot, utilities, permits, taxes, financing charges, building costs, and contingency allowance come to?  Talk with a banker about how much you can afford.  Talk with a build-on-your-lot builder about how much house you can get for that budget.  Consider a new mobile or manufactured home.  But if you do choose one, ask your banker how that affects what you can borrow, and how it affects your rates and terms.  Talk with a good real estate agent about how much the resale value might be. Finished lot budget. How much can you budget for the lot, utilities, permits required to get zoning approval, fees, interest, and taxes before you start construction? Down payment.  It sounds like you have a plan for this. Loan underwriting.  Talk with a good bank loan officer about what their expectations are.  Ask about the "front-end" and "back-end" Debt-To-Income ratios.  In Oregon, I recommend Washington Federal for lot loans and construction loans.  They keep all of their loans, and service the loans themselves.  They use appraisers who are specially trained in evaluating new home construction.  Their appraisers tend to appraise a bit low, but not ridiculously low like the incompetent appraisers used by some other banks in the area.  (I know two banks with lots of Oregon branches that use an appraiser who ignores 40% of the finished, heated area of some to-be-built homes.)  Avoid any institution (including USAA and NavyFed) that outsources their lending to PHH. Lot loan.  In Oregon, Washington Federal offers lot loans with 30% down payments, 20-year amortization, and one point, on approved credit.  The interest rate can be a fixed rate, but is typically a few percentage points per year higher than for a mortgage secured by a permanent house.  If you have the financial wherewithal to start building within two years, Washington Federal also offers short-term lot loans.  Ask about the costs of appraisals, points, and recording fees. Rent.  How much will it cost to rent a place to live, between when you move back to Oregon, and when your new home is ready to move into? Commute.  How much time will it take to get from your new home to work?  How much will it cost?  (E.g., car ownership, depreciation, maintenance, insurance, taxes, fuel?  If public transportation is an option, how much will it cost?) Lot availability.  How many are there to choose from?  Can you talk a farmer into selling off a chunk of land?  Can you homestead government land?  How much does a lot cost?  Is it worth getting a double lot (or an extra large lot)? Utilities. Do you want to live off the grid?  Are you willing to make the choices needed to do that?  (E.g., well, generator, septic system, satellite TV and telephony, fuel storage)  If not, how much will it cost to connect to such systems?  (For practical purposes, subtract twice the value of these installation costs from the cost of a finished lot, when comparing lot deals.) Easements. These provide access to your property, access for others through your property, and affect your rights.  Utility companies often ask for far more rights than they need.  Until you sign on the dotted line, you can negotiate them down to just what they need.  Talk to a good real estate attorney. Zoning. How much will you be allowed to build?  (In terms of home square footage, garage square footage, roof area, and impermeable surfaces.)  How can the home be used?  (As a business, as a farm, how many unrelated people can live there, etc.)  What setbacks are required?  How tall can the building(s) be?  Are there setbacks from streams, swamps, ponds, wetlands, or steep slopes? Choosing a builder.  For construction loans, banks want builders who will build what is agreed upon, in a timely fashion.  If you want to build your own house, talk to your loan officer about what the bank expects in a builder. Plansets and permits.  The construction loan process. If you hire a general contractor, and if you have difficulties with the contractor, you might be forced to refuse to accept some work as being complete.  A good bank will back you up.  Ask about points, appraisal charges, and inspection fees. Insurance during construction.  Some companies have good plans -- if the construction takes 12 months or less.  Some (but not all) auto insurance companies also offer good homeowners' insurance for homes under construction.  Choose your auto insurance company accordingly. Property taxes. Don't forget to include them in your post-construction budget. Homeowners' insurance.  Avoid properties that need flood insurance.  Apply a sanity check to flood maps -- some of them are unrealistic.  Strongly consider earthquake insurance.  Don't forget to include these costs in your post-construction budget. Energy costs.  Some jurisdictions require you to calculate how large a heating system you need.  Do not trust their design temperatures -- they may not allow for enough heating during a cold snap, especially if you have a heat pump.  (Some heat pumps work at -10°F -- but most lose their effectiveness between 10°F and 25°F.)  You can use these calculations, in combination with the number of "heating degree days" and "cooling degree days" at your site, to accurately estimate your energy bills.  If you choose a mobile or manufactured home, calculate how much extra its energy bills will be. Home design.  Here are some good sources of ideas: A Pattern Language, by Christopher Alexander.  Alexander emphasizes building homes and neighborhoods that can grow, and that have niches within niches within niches. The Not-So-Big House, by Sarah Susanka.  This book applies many Alexander's design patterns to medium and large new houses. Before the Architect.  The late Ralph Pressel emphasized the importance of plywood sheathing, flashing, pocket doors, wide hallways, wide stairways, attic trusses, and open-truss or I-joist floor systems.  Lots of outlets and incandescent lighting are good too.  (It is possible to have too much detail in a house plan, and too much room in a house.  For examples, see any of his plans.) Tim Garrison, "the builder's engineer".  Since Oregon is in earthquake country -- and the building codes do not fully reflect that risk -- emphasize that you want a building that would meet San Jose, California's earthquake code.
data.label: human

data.text:
Certainly! Here’s a rephrased version of the paragraph:

Are you able to purchase land? Consider these essential factors, which Alan and Denise Fields explore further in their book *Your New House*. 

**Permanent Employment**: Reflect on your preferred living location. Are there suitable job opportunities nearby? What are the typical salaries?

**Emergency Fund**: Banks appreciate having "reserves" (or an unsecured line of credit) to cover unexpected expenses or difficulties, which can also assist with managing substantial costs when securing a loan.

**Personal Line of Credit**: Consider your future plans. If you're not married, think about how purchasing a home could affect this aspect of your life—whether it simplifies or complicates things. For those planning children, assess if the home supports this decision. Married couples should ensure both partners participate in decisions regarding priorities and preferences. Unmarried individuals might wonder what their next steps will be upon marriage.

**Total Budget**: Determine how much you can allocate for land costs, utilities, permits, taxes, financing fees, construction expenses, and a contingency fund. Consult with a banker about your financial capacity and discuss potential home sizes with a builder on your lot within this budget. Consider alternatives like mobile or manufactured homes, and inquire about their impact on borrowing capacity.

**Finished Lot Budget**: Estimate the costs for utilities, permits, zoning approvals, fees, interest, and taxes before construction begins.

**Down Payment**: Having a plan in place is advisable.

**Loan Underwriting**: Discuss expectations with a seasoned bank loan officer. Ask about the "front-end" and "back-end" Debt-To-Income ratios. In Oregon, Washington Federal is recommended for lot loans and construction loans due to their retention of all loans and self-service approach. Their appraisers are trained in evaluating new home constructions.

**Choosing a Builder**: For construction loans, banks prefer builders who complete projects as agreed and within the timeline. If building independently, verify the bank's builder requirements with your loan officer.

**Construction Loan Process**: Engage a general contractor if necessary and be prepared for potential issues that might lead to disputes over completed work. Ensure your bank supports you in these situations.

**Insurance During Construction**: Seek insurance plans suited for construction periods up to 12 months, as some auto insurers also offer coverage for homes under construction.

**Property Taxes & Insurance**: Include property taxes and homeowners' insurance in your post-construction budget. Avoid properties requiring flood insurance; apply a practical approach to flood maps. Consider earthquake insurance due to the potential risks in earthquake-prone areas like Oregon.

**Energy Costs**: Some regions require calculations for heating systems based on design temperatures, but verify these calculations as they might underestimate needs during colder spells. Use "heating degree days" and "cooling degree days" to estimate energy expenses accurately. For mobile or manufactured homes, account for increased energy costs.

**Home Design**: Explore design inspirations from books like *A Pattern Language* by Christopher Alexander, which emphasizes adaptable homes, and *The Not-So-Big House* by Sarah Susanka that applies these principles to larger houses. Ralph Pressel’s insights in *Before the Architect*, including structural elements like plywood sheathing and attic trusses, can be beneficial, especially considering Oregon's earthquake risks.

By carefully considering each of these aspects, you'll be better equipped for purchasing land and planning your home effectively.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: Can stock market gains be better protected under an LLC arrangement? The thing you get wrong is that you think the LLC doesn't pay taxes on gains when it sells assets.  It does. In fact, in many countries LLC are considered separate entities for tax properties and you have double taxation - the LLC pays its own taxes, and then when you withdraw the money from the LLC to your own account (i.e.: take dividends) - you pay income tax on the withdrawal again. Corporate entities usually do not have preferential tax treatment for investments. In the US, LLC is a pass-though entity (unless explicitly chosen to be taxed as a corporation, and then the above scenario happens). Pass-through entities (LLCs and partnerships) don't pay taxes, but instead report the gains to the owners, which then pay taxes as if the transaction was their personal one. So if you're in the US - investing under LLC would have no effect whatsoever on your taxes, or adverse effect if you chose to treat it as a corporation. In any case, investing in stocks is not a deductible expense, and as such doesn't reduce profits.
data.label: human

data.text: Is it possible to enhance the protection of stock market gains within an LLC structure? The misunderstanding arises from believing that an LLC does not incur taxes on asset sales. However, this is incorrect. In many countries, LLCs are regarded as separate taxable entities, leading to double taxation: the LLC pays its own taxes, and then you face income tax again when withdrawing funds (such as dividends) into your personal account. Generally, corporate structures do not receive favorable tax treatment for investments. In the U.S., an LLC is a pass-through entity unless it opts to be taxed as a corporation, in which case double taxation applies. Pass-through entities like LLCs and partnerships report gains directly to owners, who then pay taxes as if they were personally involved in the transactions. Therefore, investing through an LLC in the U.S. would neither affect your tax situation nor provide any advantage unless treated as a corporation. Additionally, stock investments are not deductible expenses and thus do not reduce profits.

data.text: Does Primolut N taken during pregnancy affect the baby?Hi doctor..I have taken primoult n tablet twice daily for 5 days to delay my periods in the month of march.I was not aware of the pregnancy at that time but now when I tested in April month it is positive in pregnancy.so my question here is does this tablet effect my baby Hi,     Thanks for the query. I understand your concern.         Primolute  N-a hormonal preparation of female sex hormone... is contraindicated in pregnancy.      It can cause fetal congenital abnormality &so such pregnancy (with intake of pills like promolute n ) needs to be terminated.   Thanks.

data.text:
Does taking Primolut-N during pregnancy affect the baby?  
Hello doctor, I took a Primolut-N tablet twice daily for five days in March to delay my period without knowing I was pregnant at that time. When I tested in April, it turned out positive. My question is whether this medication affects my baby. Thank you.

Thank you for your query; I understand your concern.  
Primolut-N is a hormonal preparation of female sex hormones and is contraindicated during pregnancy. It can lead to fetal congenital abnormalities, so pregnancies involving the intake of such pills may need to be terminated. Thank you.

data.text:
Original: Bloating and pain on the right lower abdomen. Should I see a doctor? I have many symptoms of appendicitis, such as bloating and pain in the right lower abdomen; pressure on the left side also triggers pain. It is 1:30 am where I am. Should I try to contact my doctor or go to the hospital? I'm 77 but otherwise in good health.

Response: Thank you for reaching out to H.C.M. Forum. You're experiencing pain on the right side of your lower abdomen, which could be due to several causes:

1. Right renal colic, confirmed via an abdominal ultrasound.
2. Amoebic colitis, a common possibility at this age; diagnosis through physical examination is possible.
3. Appendicitis, less likely in your age group.

I suggest consulting your physician for their opinion. If the pain is manageable, there's no need to visit the ER immediately. Good luck. - Dr. HET

Should I try to contact my doctor or go to the hospital? I'm 77 but otherwise in good health.

Response: Thank you for reaching out to H.C.M. Forum. You're experiencing discomfort and bloating in your right lower abdomen, which could be due to various reasons:

1. Right-sided renal colic, which can be verified with an abdominal ultrasound.
2. Amoebic colitis, a common condition at your age; diagnosis is possible through a physical examination.
3. Appendicitis, though less probable given your age group.

It would be wise to get in touch with your physician for their opinion. If the pain remains bearable, you may not need to go to the ER right away. Wishing you well. - Dr. HET

If both are normal then no need to worry for heart diseases. Sometimes gastritis and GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) can cause similar symptoms. So avoid prolonged sitting. data.text: Will the pain while peeing be due to kidney stone or UTI?I have a history with kidney stones and normally when i have one i get pain toward the end of urination in my clitorus. i Just got off of an antibiotic for a sinus infection and got a yeast infection and treated it with the 3 day monastat stuff. and now im feeling that pain again in my clit when i pee. is it just a kidney store or is it a UTI, also have some pain during intercorse HelloThanks for query .Pain at the urination is mostly due to infection of Bladder (Cystitis) however since you are known to have history of kidney stone possibility of urinary stone needs to be ruled out .Please consult qualified Urologist for clinical  examination and get following basic tests done to confirm the diagnosis.1) Urine routine and culture.2) Ultrasound scanning of abdomen and pelvisTake broad spectrum antibiotics like Cefixime   along with urinary antiseptic like Nitrofurantoin twice daily and urine alkalizer thrice daily .Later on switch on to appropriate antibiotics as per culture report.Get the prescription of medicines from your family Physician.Ensure to drink more water .To keep your urine dilute This will help to control dysuria.Dr.Patil.
data.label: human

data.text:
Certainly, here's a rephrased version:

Are you experiencing pain during urination due to kidney stones or a urinary tract infection (UTI)? Given your history of kidney stones, which typically cause discomfort towards the end of urination near the clitoris, it seems pertinent to consider this possibility. Recently, after completing an antibiotic course for a sinus infection and subsequently treating a yeast infection with Monistat over three days, you're again feeling pain in that area during urination. Could this indicate another kidney stone or perhaps a UTI? Additionally, is there any discomfort during intercourse?

The pain associated with urination often stems from bladder infections (cystitis), but considering your history with kidney stones, it's crucial to rule out the possibility of urinary stones as well. I recommend consulting a qualified urologist for a clinical examination and conducting some basic tests to confirm the diagnosis, including:

1) A routine urine test and culture.
2) An ultrasound scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

In the interim, taking broad-spectrum antibiotics like Cefixime along with a urinary antiseptic such as Nitrofurantoin twice daily, and a urine alkalizer thrice daily may be beneficial. Once you receive your culture report, switch to more targeted antibiotics as prescribed by your healthcare provider. Ensure to obtain prescriptions from your family physician.

Drinking plenty of water is essential to dilute your urine, which can help alleviate dysuria (painful urination).  

- Dr. Patil

Hello,Bronchitis or lung disease with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is generally not associated with asthma and your sister needs a full respiratory evaluation.Chest X Ray is not a sensitive test, so a HRCT (high resolution CT scan) will be required to see the lymph nodes in detail.There are several conditions especially infections that present with enlarged lymph nodes and present with shortness of breath (appears like asthma) and hence the requirement of a full check.Lung function tests (pulmonary function tests) with diffusion capacity is required as well. A bronschopy may be required after the HRCT scan.Blood tests: Complete hemogram, Liver function tests, ACE level, IgE, Urea Creatinine, ANA, ANCA are also required.A treatment plan can be decided only after these tests are done.I hope that was useful.Best Wishes.

Bronchitis or lung disease with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy typically isn't related to asthma, so a comprehensive respiratory evaluation is necessary for your sister. A chest X-ray lacks sensitivity; therefore, an HRCT (high-resolution CT scan) is essential to examine the lymph nodes closely. data.text: Q. How can brown teeth due to fluoride be treated?Hi doctor, My probleam is my tooth and the color of my tooth is completly brown, this happen becouse of flouride. Based on this is possible to remove brown colour to white and how much does it cost? Hi. I have seen the picture attached along with your complaint (attachment removed to protect patient identity). You have severe dental fluorosis along with severe external stains. It is definitely possible to get whiter teeth with the help of dental veneers. Firstly the procedure includes complete thorough cleaning of the stains. Secondly the teeth visible in your smile zone will have to be prepared (ground slightly on the front surfaces) to fix in the dental veneers. Coming to the cost of the procedure,there are two types of veneers. One is composite veneers which has to be done in the clinic manually by the dentist. But this has short life and a major disadvantage of discoloration. Two, ceramic dental veneers which have to be made in the laboratory and then fixed on the prepared teeth. Ceramic ones are much suitable for you as it can long last and hide the brownish colour of your present teeth to a greater extent but this is expensive than composite ones. data.text:
**Rephrased Paragraph:**

Q. How can brown teeth caused by fluoride be treated?  
Hi doctor, My issue is that my teeth are completely brown due to fluoride exposure. Is it possible to remove this discoloration and achieve a whiter color, and what would the cost be?  

Hi. I've reviewed your attached picture (attachment removed for privacy). You have severe dental fluorosis along with significant external staining. Achieving whiter teeth through dental veneers is definitely feasible. The process begins with an extensive cleaning of the stains. Next, the teeth in your smile zone will need to be slightly reshaped on their front surfaces to fit the veneers properly. Regarding costs, there are two types of veneers: composite and ceramic. Composite veneers, created manually by the dentist during a clinic visit, have a shorter lifespan and may discolor over time. Ceramic veneers, fabricated in a lab and then affixed to your teeth, offer greater durability and better concealment of brownish tones, though they come at a higher price than composite ones. Prices for ceramic veneers vary depending on the dentist and the laboratory. It's best to discuss with your dentist to find the most suitable option within your budget.

Subsequently, the front surfaces of your teeth within your smile area will need minor reshaping to ensure a proper fit for the veneers. In terms of costs, there are two varieties: composite and ceramic. Composite veneers, crafted by the dentist during a single clinic visit, tend to have a shorter lifespan and might yellow over time. Ceramic veneers, made in a lab before being attached to your teeth, offer enhanced durability and better masking of brownish hues but come with a higher price tag compared to composite ones. It would be beneficial to consult with your dentist to determine the most appropriate choice that fits within your budget.

The symptoms last around 3-4 days before improving and then disappearing, only to return after another 5-7 days. Hello,

Welcome to the discussion. While recurrent respiratory tract infections are relatively common, having more than six to twelve episodes annually is unusual. It's possible that an inadequately or partially treated case might present in such a way. I hope this helps with your concern.

Thank you.

Welcome to HCM. Thank you for sharing your concern. It's likely that the lumps under your jaw are swollen lymph nodes, often due to an infection. Other potential causes might include a dental abscess or swelling from a blocked duct of the submandibular gland.

Here are some recommendations:
- Apply warm compresses to the affected areas 2-3 times daily.
- Stay hydrated by drinking at least eight glasses of water each day.
- Avoid cold beverages and refrain from smoking and alcohol consumption.

Please consult an ENT specialist for a thorough diagnosis. The doctor may examine the area or recommend a CT scan to determine the exact cause or rule out other possibilities. They might prescribe antibiotics if there's an infection or medication for any underlying condition.

If dental issues are identified, you'll be referred to a dentist. Treatment options for a dental abscess include a root canal, extraction, or minor surgery. I hope this helps address your concern. Best wishes, Dr. Harry Maheshwari

It looks like little red pin prick spots that are raised she doesnt have a fever and not itchy. Please help. Hi,I feel by what you quote he should be having a - Hand Foot Mouth disease. This is one viral illness among all other exanthemas which can cause fever followed by rash over palms and soles. It is a self-limiting disorder and itching can be really worrisome. I suggest you to use any over the counter antihistamine if you have one with you now. You can use Hydroxyzine at 1-2 mg/kg/dose (Maximum 10mg) every 6th to 8th hourly for 7 days. This can even cause some peeling of skin in the next 4-6 weeks and do not worry about it.Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards, Dr. Sumanth

data.text:
**Original Paragraph:**  
What causes rashes on torso, face, and arms in an infant? Hi Doctor, I have a 8-month-old daughter who has just broken out with a rash that started over her torso, then to her face, now on her arms and legs. It looks like little red pinprick spots that are raised; she doesn't have a fever and it's not itchy. Please help.

**Response:**  
Hello,

Based on your description, it sounds like your daughter may be experiencing Hand Foot Mouth disease. This viral illness can cause rashes similar to what you've described, often starting with small red raised spots. Although typically accompanied by a fever, your daughter is fortunate that she doesn't have one or any itching.

To help manage her discomfort, consider using an over-the-counter antihistamine if available. I recommend Hydroxyzine at 1-2 mg/kg per dose (up to a maximum of 10mg) every 6 to 8 hours for seven days. It’s normal for the skin to peel a bit in the following four to six weeks, so there's no need to worry about that.

I hope this addresses your concerns. Please feel free to reach out if you have further questions.

Best regards,  
Dr. Sumanth

What causes bumps on the shaft? I noticed a few 1mm-sized bumps spaced about 1 to 2 centimeters apart on my shaft. They initially appeared after one or two instances of manual stimulation and intercourse, followed by masturbation the next day, which seemed to spread them. There's no itching, burning, or discharge associated with these bumps. Occasionally, I spot a white dot, usually indicating a hair, but not always present. It’s been two weeks, and they seem to be gradually fading away.

Hello,

Considering it occurred post-sex, here are some possibilities:

1. **Genital Warts (HPV):** This can manifest as painful blisters, yellow sores, or red bases. While there's no cure for genital herpes, treatments focus on symptom relief, faster healing, and reducing the duration of symptoms.

2. **Syphilis:** If the bumps aren't painful, consider syphilis, where initial blisters might appear as primary symptoms. They often disappear on their own but can persist in the body. It's crucial to seek medical attention if such blisters appear.

3. **Molluscum Contagiosum:** This condition involves small, painless bumps. Testing for HIV, VDRL, and a complete urine analysis is advisable.

data.text:
Is there an alternative to penicillin in homeopathy?  
Hello,  
My 8-year-old child has mild Sydenham's chorea without any previous signs of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF). The EEG, MRI scan, and videocardiogram show no damage. Is there a homeopathic remedy or substitute for the penicillin he needs to take for at least another decade?  
Thank you, Svetla  

1. Since chorea is a delayed symptom of rheumatic fever [Jones major criteria], it can appear after a long latent period from an antecedent streptococcal infection. Thus, other manifestations (ARF/EEG/MRI) might be normal when chorea appears. Regular supervision and follow-up are necessary.  
2. Ensure the attending physician examines for any valvular lesions, checks for exophthalmos, butterfly rash on the face, signs of hepatocellular failure, K-F rings in the cornea, or polycythemia.  
3. Penicillin remains the safest and preferred medication for this condition to prevent infections and complications like Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (SABE). In Ayurveda, alongside penicillin, we use immunomodulators to boost immunity, helping ward off opportunistic infections. [Please consult a local expert]
data.label: qwen_1

Is there an alternative to penicillin within homeopathy?  
Hello,  

My 8-year-old child has mild Sydenham's chorea without any preceding symptoms of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF). The EEG, MRI scan, and videocardiogram show no damage. Is there a homeopathic remedy or substitute for the penicillin he needs to take for at least another decade?  
Thank you, Svetla  

1. Since chorea is a delayed symptom of rheumatic fever [Jones major criteria], it can manifest after a prolonged latent period following an initial streptococcal infection. Therefore, other manifestations (ARF/EEG/MRI) might appear normal when chorea arises. Regular monitoring and follow-ups are essential.

In Ayurveda, along with penicillin, immunomodulators are used to enhance immunity, aiding in preventing opportunistic infections. [Please consult a local expert]

data.text: what composer used sound mass Composers and works include Barbara Kolb , Pauline Oliveros ' Sound Patterns for chorus (1961), Norma Beecroft 's From Dreams of Brass for chorus (1963–1964), and Nancy Van de Vate .A very early example is the opening of Jean-Féry Rebel 's ballet Les Elémens (1737–38), where chaos is represented by a gradually cumulating orchestral cluster of all seven notes of the D minor scale (Henck 2004, pp. 52–54).A later example is the third movement of Ruth Crawford Seeger 's String Quartet 1931 (Nonesuch H-71280) while more recently Phill Niblock 's multiple drone based music serves as an example.The use of "chords approaching timbres" begins with Debussy and Edgard Varèse often carefully scored individual instrumental parts so that they would fuse into one ensemble timbre or sound mass (Erickson 1975, pp. 18 and 21).Other examples include European "textural" compositions of the fifties and sixties such as Krzysztof Penderecki 's Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima (1959) and György Ligeti 's works featuring micropolyphony in works like Atmosphères (1961) and his Requiem (1963-65).Other composers with works using this technique include Henryk Górecki , Karel Husa , Witold Lutosławski , Kazimierz Serocki , and Steven Stucky .Sound mass techniques also appear in the music of George Crumb (Anon. n.d.).
data.label: human

data.text:
The concept of sound mass has been utilized by various composers, including Barbara Kolb, Pauline Oliveros with her "Sound Patterns for Chorus" (1961), Norma Beecroft's "From Dreams of Brass for Chorus" (1963–1964), and Nancy Van de Vate. An early instance is found in the opening of Jean-Féry Rebel's ballet "Les Éléments" (1737–38), where chaos is depicted through a gradually building orchestral cluster encompassing all seven notes of the D minor scale (Henck 2004, pp. 52–54). Another example is the third movement of Ruth Crawford Seeger's String Quartet 1931 (Nonesuch H-71280), while more contemporary instances include Phill Niblock’s multiple drone-based compositions.

The technique of "chords approaching timbres" originates with Debussy and Edgard Varèse, who meticulously scored individual instrumental parts to blend into a unified ensemble timbre or sound mass (Erickson 1975, pp. 18 and 21). Further examples are found in European textural compositions from the 1950s and 1960s, such as Krzysztof Penderecki's "Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima" (1959) and György Ligeti’s works that incorporate micropolyphony, evident in pieces like "Atmosphères" (1961) and his Requiem (1963-65). Other composers who have employed this technique include Henryk Górecki, Karel Husa, Witold Lutosławski, Kazimierz Serocki, and Steven Stucky. Additionally, George Crumb's music also features sound mass techniques (Anon. n.d.).
data.label: qwen_1

data.text:
The idea of using sound mass has been adopted by several composers such as Barbara Kolb, Pauline Oliveros in her "Sound Patterns for Chorus" (1961), Norma Beecroft’s "From Dreams of Brass for Chorus" (1963–1964), and Nancy Van de Vate. An early example can be found at the beginning of Jean-Féry Rebel's ballet "Les Éléments" (1737–38), where chaos is represented through an orchestral cluster that gradually intensifies, covering all seven notes of the D minor scale (Henck 2004, pp. 52–54). Another instance is in the third movement of Ruth Crawford Seeger’s String Quartet 1931 (Nonesuch H-71280), while more recent examples include Phill Niblock's drone-based compositions.

The method known as "chords approaching timbres" was pioneered by Debussy and Edgard Varèse, who carefully arranged individual instrumental parts to merge into a cohesive ensemble timbre or sound mass (Erickson 1975, pp. 18 and 21). Additional examples appear in European textural works from the 1950s and 1960s, such as Krzysztof Penderecki's "Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima" (1959) and György Ligeti’s pieces that feature micropolyphony, notably "Atmosphères" (1961) and his Requiem (1963-65). Composers like Henryk Górecki, Karel Husa, Witold Lutosławski, Kazimierz Serocki, and Steven Stucky have also utilized this technique. Furthermore, George Crumb’s compositions incorporate sound mass techniques as well (Anon. n.d.).

data.text: where did the persian war take place The Greco-Persian Wars (also often called the Persian Wars) were a series of conflicts between the Achaemenid Empire of Persia and city-states of the Hellenic world that started in 499 BC and lasted until 449 BC.In 494 BC, the Persians regrouped, and attacked the epicentre of the revolt in Miletus.At the Battle of Lade , the Ionians suffered a decisive defeat, and the rebellion collapsed, with the final members being stamped out the following year.Seeking to secure his empire from further revolts and from the interference of the mainland Greeks, Darius embarked on a scheme to conquer Greece and to punish Athens and Eretria for burning Sardis.The actions of the general Pausanias at the siege of Byzantium alienated many of the Greek states from the Spartans, and the anti-Persian alliance was therefore reconstituted around Athenian leadership, as the so-called Delian League .At the Battle of the Eurymedon in 466 BC, the League won a double victory that finally secured freedom for the cities of Ionia.A fleet was sent to Cyprus in 451 BC, but achieved little, and when it withdrew the Greco-Persian Wars drew to a quiet end.
data.label: human

data.text:
The Persian War took place where exactly? The conflicts known as the Greco-Persian Wars (or simply the Persian Wars) were a series of battles between the Achaemenid Empire of Persia and the city-states of the Hellenic world, spanning from 499 BC to 449 BC. In 494 BC, after regrouping, the Persians launched an attack on Miletus, the heart of the revolt. The Ionians faced a crushing defeat at the Battle of Lade, leading to the collapse of the rebellion; the last remnants were eliminated by the following year. To prevent further uprisings and interference from mainland Greece, Darius planned to conquer Greece, aiming to punish Athens and Eretria for burning Sardis.

The actions of Spartan general Pausanias during the siege of Byzantium led many Greek states to distance themselves from Sparta. Consequently, the anti-Persian alliance was reestablished under Athenian leadership, forming what became known as the Delian League. At the Battle of Eurymedon in 466 BC, the League achieved a double victory that secured independence for Ionia's cities. In 451 BC, although a fleet was sent to Cyprus with minimal success, its withdrawal marked the gradual end of the Greco-Persian Wars.
data.label: qwen_1

Could you specify the precise location of the Persian War? The conflicts known as the Greco-Persian Wars (or simply the Persian Wars) involved a series of battles between the Achaemenid Empire of Persia and the city-states of the Hellenic world, occurring from 499 BC to 449 BC. In 494 BC, after regrouping, the Persians attacked Miletus, which was central to the revolt. The Ionians suffered a devastating defeat at the Battle of Lade, leading to the rebellion's downfall; by the following year, any remaining resistance had been quashed. To avoid further uprisings and interference from mainland Greece, Darius intended to conquer Greece, intending to punish Athens and Eretria for burning Sardis.

The conduct of Spartan general Pausanias during the siege of Byzantium caused many Greek states to distance themselves from Sparta. As a result, the anti-Persian alliance was reestablished under Athenian leadership, forming what became known as the Delian League. The Battle of Eurymedon in 466 BC saw the League secure a double victory that ensured the independence of Ionia's cities. In 451 BC, although an expedition to Cyprus achieved minimal success, its withdrawal signified the gradual conclusion of the Greco-Persian Wars.

data.text: how does a dredge work? Dredging is an excavation activity or operation usually carried out at least partly underwater, in shallow seas or fresh water areas with the purpose of gathering up bottom sediments and disposing of them at a different location.A dredger (or “dredge” as is the general usage in the Americas) is any device, machine, or vessel that is used to excavate and remove material from the bottom of a body of water.For example, a scoop attached to the end of a rope or pole by which a man can draw sediments up from the bottom of a pond is a dredger.Developing this idea further, a motorized crane equipped with a drag bucket or clamshell (grabber) that is used to scoop material from the bottom of a body of water is also a dredger.If the crane is mounted on a barge, the entire vessel is referred to as a dredger.
data.label: human

data.text:
How does a dredge operate? Dredging involves an excavation process typically conducted partially or entirely underwater in shallow marine environments or freshwater regions with the aim of collecting bottom sediments and relocating them elsewhere.

A dredger (commonly known simply as "dredge" in the Americas) refers to any apparatus, machine, or vessel designed to excavate and remove material from a water body's floor. For instance, a scoop connected to a rope or pole that enables a person to lift sediments from a pond's bottom qualifies as a dredger.

Expanding on this concept, a motorized crane equipped with either a drag bucket or clamshell (grabber) used for scooping material from the base of a water body also serves as a dredger. When such a crane is installed on a barge, the entire setup is termed a dredger.
data.label: qwen_1

Expanding on this idea, a motorized crane equipped with either a drag bucket or clamshell (grabber) for collecting materials from the base of a water body also functions as a dredger. When such a crane is mounted on a barge, the entire configuration is known as a dredger.

data.text: What subjects fall under humanities? The humanities encompass academic fields focused on studying human culture through primarily analytical, critical, or speculative methods, often incorporating a substantial historical component. Additionally, some humanities disciplines overlap with social sciences, such as history, anthropology, area studies, communication studies, cultural studies, law, economics, and linguistics. Disciplines in the humanities, including history, cultural anthropology, and psychoanalysis, explore topics that are not suited to experimental methods but rather utilize comparative methodologies and research approaches.

data.text: What is Atherosclerotic Heart Disease? Atherosclerosis, also known as arteriosclerotic vascular disease (ASVD), is a condition characterized by the thickening of an artery wall due to the buildup of fatty substances like cholesterol and triglycerides. It represents a syndrome affecting arterial blood vessels, involving a chronic inflammatory response in the arterial walls primarily triggered by the accumulation of macrophage white blood cells. This process is further promoted by low-density lipoproteins (LDL), which are plasma proteins that transport cholesterol and triglycerides, without sufficient clearance of fats and cholesterol from macrophages by functional high-density lipoproteins (HDL). This condition is often referred to as the hardening or clogging of arteries. It results from the formation of multiple plaques within the arteries.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: What constitutes Atherosclerotic Heart Disease? Also known as arteriosclerotic vascular disease (ASVD), atherosclerosis is characterized by the thickening of an artery wall due to the accumulation of fatty substances, such as cholesterol and triglycerides. This condition affects arterial blood vessels and involves a chronic inflammatory response in the arterial walls, mainly caused by macrophage white blood cells. The process is further exacerbated by low-density lipoproteins (LDL), which are plasma proteins responsible for transporting cholesterol and triglycerides, especially when there isn't adequate clearance of fats and cholesterol from macrophages by functional high-density lipoproteins (HDL). Often described as the hardening or clogging of arteries, this condition arises from the formation of multiple plaques within the arteries.

data.text: how are antibodies used in An antibody (Ab), also known as an immunoglobulin (Ig), is a large Y-shaped protein produced by B-cells that is used by the immune system to identify and neutralize foreign objects such as bacteria and viruses .The antibody recognizes a unique part of the foreign target, called an antigen .Each tip of the "Y" of an antibody contains a paratope (a structure analogous to a lock) that is specific for one particular epitope (similarly analogous to a key) on an antigen, allowing these two structures to bind together with precision.Using this binding mechanism, an antibody can tag a microbe or an infected cell for attack by other parts of the immune system, or can neutralize its target directly (for example, by blocking a part of a microbe that is essential for its invasion and survival).

data.text:
Antibodies, also known as immunoglobulins, are large Y-shaped proteins synthesized by B-cells. They serve a crucial role in the immune system by identifying and neutralizing foreign entities such as bacteria and viruses. An antibody specifically recognizes a unique segment of these foreign targets called an antigen. Each end of the "Y" shape on an antibody contains a paratope, which is akin to a lock and matches precisely with one specific epitope (comparable to a key) on the antigen, enabling them to bind together accurately.

This binding mechanism allows antibodies to mark microbes or infected cells for destruction by other immune components or directly neutralize their targets. For instance, an antibody may obstruct a vital part of a microbe that is necessary for its invasion and survival.

data.text:
How do forensic auditors scrutinize financial reporting? The audit opinion aims to offer reasonable assurance—not absolute certainty—that the financial statements accurately reflect all material aspects and/or present a true and fair view, adhering to the relevant financial reporting framework. An audit's purpose is to conduct an objective, independent evaluation of the financial statements, thereby enhancing their value and credibility as produced by management. This process boosts user confidence in the financial statements, diminishes investor risk, and subsequently lowers the preparer’s cost of capital.

Financial audits are generally carried out by accounting firms comprised of practicing accountants who possess expertise in financial reporting.

data.text:
Keith Whitley, whose full name is Jackie Keith Whitley (born July 1, 1954), hailed from Kentucky, according to Stambler, Irwin, and Grelun Landon in their "Country Music: The Encyclopedia" published by St. Martin's Press in New York, on page 533 with ISBN 978-0-312-26487-1. Richard Carlin also references him in "Country Music: A Biographical Dictionary," published by Routledge in New York, on page 427 and carrying the ISBN 978-0-415-93802-0. Colin Larkin mentions Whitley in "The Guinness Encyclopedia of Popular Music," brought out by Stockton Press in New York, on page 4462 with ISBN 978-0-85112-662-3. Further references to him can be found in Scott Stanton's "The Tombstone Tourist: Musicians" published by Pocket Books in New York, on page 395 and bearing the ISBN 978-0-7434-6330-0.

Jack Hicks wrote about Whitley in an article titled "Singer Keith Whitley's Memory Alive Through Songs, Love in Home Town" for The Kentucky Post on September 25, 1991. His untimely death was reported by the Lexington Herald-Leader in an article entitled "Country Music Star Keith Whitley Dead at 33," dated May 10, 1989, while Jack Hurst detailed his final days in "Whitley's Last Days" for the Chicago Tribune on May 14, 1989. Additionally, United Press International reported that alcohol was responsible for his death, as cited by The San Francisco Chronicle on May 10, 1989, although this article was initially published on May 9, 1989. Whitley gained recognition professionally under the name Keith Whitley and was celebrated as an American country music singer.

data.text:
Why are there still SD TV channels when HD looks like SD on an older TV? Couldn't we just have the HD versions and remove the SD ones? Let me explain simply. Back in the day, television stations were given a set amount of bandwidth to replace their old analog channels. However, HD requires more bandwidth than SD does. This means that a station could choose either 2 or 3 HD channels, or about 7 or 8 SD channels—or some combination of both.

Many stations opt for multiple SD channels because it allows them to make more money from advertising by airing several reruns of old shows at once. Interestingly, these stations often hold permanent rights to broadcast an unlimited number of reruns of certain syndicated shows forever. This means they don't have to pay anything to air episodes of classics like *Star Trek* or *Alf*. Essentially, it's free money for them because they've been around a long time and their old broadcasting rights automatically improve as new technology emerges.

Consequently, a station could either offer 2 or 3 HD channels or around 7 or 8 SD channels—or even a mix of both.

Many stations choose to broadcast multiple SD channels as it enables them to generate additional advertising revenue by airing numerous reruns of older shows simultaneously. Interestingly, these stations often hold perpetual rights to air an unlimited number of reruns for certain syndicated programs at no cost. This means they don't need to pay to show episodes of classics like *Star Trek* or *Alf*. EDIT , Nov 21 : By popular demand , now includes Midrange decks and Limited formats . Also , a new section on where players get their cards . Magic : The Gathering is a collectable card game . It can be played in several different formats , but in the most common , two players create decks out of the cards they own and play against each other . Generally , the cards in a deck are either lands or spells . Lands provide the energy needed to cast spells , and spells usually do one of the following : - Summon a creature that can fight for you or an artifact that you can use . ( * * Creatures * * and * * Artifacts * * ) - Create a lasting effect that affects the game as a whole or one or more cards in play . ( * * Enchantments * * ) - Create an instantaneous effect that affects one or more cards in play or an effect that lasts a single turn . ( * * Sorceries * * and * * Instants * * ) - Summon a sort of " teammate " that has its own abilities . ( * * Planeswalkers * * ) The primary goal is to run your opponent out of life points by attacking him with creatures or damaging him directly with spells . There are other ways to win , such as running your opponent out of cards in his deck . The gameplay is complex . The players take turns , but many types of spells can be cast on an opponent 's turn , or in response to a spell that they are trying to cast . A critical play by one player may be countered by the other , and that counter itself countered by the first . There are many thousands of cards out there , and you are not expected to know about them all . The Comprehensive Rules ( * not * including the text of cards ) are nearly two hundred pages , although a lot of that consists of old mechanics that are rarely used or highly - specified details that are rarely relevant . The learning curve is pretty steep , but a few games suffice to learn the basic rules . The complexity is more similar to Dungeons and Dragons than to most card games . A key feature of M : tG is the concept of * * color * * . There are five colors : Red , Green , White , Blue , Black . Each is " allied " to two others and " opposed " to the two others . Most spells require mana of a certain color to cast , which is produced by different types of land cards . Each color has distinct strengths and weaknesses – for example , blue has the best counterspells , but it 's not very good at simply hitting things . A given deck will usually use from one to three colors of card , although in some situations decks with four or five colors can work . In addition , it is often considered that there are three general archetypes of deck ( with a * lot * of variation within each category ) : - * * Aggro * * decks focus on dealing damage ASAP to win ASAP . They usually have cheap creatures ( " weenies " ) that can be used right away and " buff"-type spells to eke out a few more points of damage . They usually win fast or not at all , because they often ca n't stand up to the more powerful creatures and spells that are played later in the game . - * * Control * * decks focus on preventing the opponent from acting until the player is ready to win with powerful spells or abilities . They run a lot of counterspells , destruction spells , and things that make action more expensive for the opponent , along with a few creatures strong on defense and disruption . They usually win by using cheap defenses against expensive attacks until they are ready to overwhelm the opponent with their accumulated strength , and lose if they just ca n't stay ahead of the enemy 's attacks . - * * Combo * * decks rely on a few combinations of cards that can lead to a near - instant victory . There * are * infinite combos in M : tG , but they 're designed to be difficult or resource - intensive to pull off . A combo deck will usually run ( in addition to the all - important combo pieces ) " tutor " cards that let them search their deck , protection cards to guard the combo pieces , and just enough stall cards to prevent a quick defeat . A combo deck wins when it gets its combo in place before losing , and loses if it ca n't get the combo out in time or ca n't protect it long enough to use it . - * * Midrange * * decks are a common intermediate archetype between Aggro and Control . Midrange tries to beat down the opponent with damage from powerful creatures ( colloquially , " fatties " ) rather than with cheap ones ( " weenies " ) . These decks have to run enough control to stay alive until the big hitters come out . They win when they get the hitters out early enough to do lethal damage , and lose when they ca n't get the big guys out at all ( being out - controlled ) or when they just take too much of a beating too early ( being out - aggro'd ) . --- Many different kinds of people play M : tG. There are professional players who win large sums at tournaments , groups of friends who play casually on the weekends , and everything in between . If you 're playing competitively , it can be absurdly expensive , as you can not compromise on getting the perfect cards for your deck , but if you and your opponents are playing casually , it 's a lot cheaper . The most common formats are as follows . Two - player games are the norm for tournaments , but casual matches are often multiplayer . * * Constructed * * formats call for pre - constructed decks built from each player 's personal collection : - * * Standard * * : Decks are made of cards printed in about the last 18 months . - * * Modern * * : Decks are made of cards printed since about 2003 ( minus a ban list ) . - * * Legacy * * : Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a ban list ) . - * * Vintage * * : Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a * very small * ban list ) . - * * Commander * * ( or " EDH " ): Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a ban list ) , but limited to one of each card . One creature card is designated as your " commander " and is nearly always available for summoning . A popular multiplayer format . * * Limited * * formats feature decks made on the spot from a limited pool of cards : - * * Sealed * * : Each player opens several randomized booster packs and makes a deck from the contents . - * * Draft * * : A group of players open many packs and use a system to pick their cards from the contents , then build a deck from what they have . These formats cost money each time to play , because you need to buy booster packs . However , you can play them without having any of your own cards beforehand . Limited play can be a good way to pick up more cards . A relatively new casual format is * * Cube * * , in which you and your group put together a large pile of cards beforehand and use them in place of booster packs . This eliminates the recurring expense , although you need to have enough cards beforehand . There are others formats , including Conspiracy , Planechase , Pauper ( use no rare cards ) . Two - Headed Giant ( play with a partner ) , and many more . Formats that allow older cards tend to be more expensive , because the cards have been out of print for a long time . Commander is a bit cheaper than other formats that allow old cards , because you only can have one of each card ( other formats usually allow up to four of each card ) . I play Commander with my D & D group . None of us puts that much money into it , and we try to keep it more fun than competitive . Some of the players also play in local mini - tournaments on Friday nights ( " Friday Night Magic " ) , usually breaking about even . --- So , where does one get cards ? Most cards come from randomized booster packs with 15 cards each . Cards from a given set are designated either common , uncommon , rare , or " mythic rare " . You can buy booster packs for around $ 3.50 USD from retailers , or you can buy them as part of a limited tournament . There are also pre - made decks that you can buy directly from Wizards of the Coast . Each one has a theme and cards intended to work together . You wo n't win any tournaments with a pre - made deck , but it can be a good starting point . In addition , there are a couple of products intended for beginners , such as the " Deck - builder 's toolkit " with a semi - randomized selection of cards and a big stack of common lands . ( Common lands are dirt cheap , but it would take quite a few booster packs to get enough to build a deck . ) Most M : tG players trade cards with their friends or at events to get the specific cards they need . In addition , there is a thriving market of single cards at game stores and online . Some very , very old cards are very , very rare and expensive . A single [ Black Lotus ] ( URL_0 ) can cost many thousands of dollars . But these cards are not legal in most formats , and most players will never have seen one in person . When playing casually , your group may allow the use of " proxy " cards to substitute for the pricey ones . Myself , I 've only been playing for a year or so , and I do n't actually own my own cards ! ( My friends have a ton of extra decks to lend out . ) I 'm planning to build my own Commander deck soon , and I 'll be starting from a pre - made deck from Wizards and supplementing it primarily with trades with friends and singles from the internet .
data.label: human

data.text:
Magic: The Gathering (MTG) is like a big, exciting card game where players use decks of cards to battle each other. Each deck has different kinds of creatures, spells, and lands that help you out in battles. Here’s how it all works, explained simply:

### Types of Cards

1. **Creatures**: These are your "units" that fight for you.
2. **Spells**: They can do special things, like healing or damaging opponents.
3. **Lands**: You use them to get the magic energy needed to play spells and creatures.

### How You Get Started

1. **Booster Packs**: These packs contain 15 cards each with different rarities—common, uncommon, rare, and mythic rare. They are a great way to start building your deck.
   
2. **Pre-Made Decks**: Wizards of the Coast sells these decks that come fully assembled. They're themed and balanced for beginners.

3. **Deck Builder’s Toolkit**: This includes some cards and lots of common lands, perfect for starting out without needing tons of booster packs.

### How to Play

1. **Constructed Formats**: You build your deck from your own collection.
   - *Standard*: Use the latest set of cards (about the last 18 months).
   - *Modern, Legacy, Vintage*: These formats allow older cards with some restrictions or bans.
   - *Commander (EDH)*: Everyone picks one "commander" creature card. You can only have one of each card in your deck.

2. **Limited Formats**: You build decks from a small pool of new cards.
   - *Sealed*: Open a few packs and make a deck with those cards.
   - *Draft*: Pick cards from shared booster packs to assemble your deck.

3. **Cube Format**: A custom set of cards created by you or a group, used like booster packs.

### Other Formats

- **Two-Headed Giant**: You team up with someone else for matches.
- **Planechase and Conspiracy**: Unique gameplay twists that change how the game is played.
- **Pauper**: Only common cards are allowed; no rares!

### Playing with Friends or Tournaments

You can play casually at home, in groups, or participate in local tournaments. There are also online versions where you can play against people from around the world.

### Where to Get Cards

- **Buy Booster Packs or Pre-Made Decks**: Available in stores and online.
- **Trade with Friends**: Many players trade cards to get what they need for their decks.
- **Online Marketplaces**: Buy single cards as needed.

### Costs

- **Expensive Formats**: Legacy, Vintage, and Commander can be pricey because of older cards' rarity and value.
- **Proxy Cards**: In casual play, you might use stand-ins for expensive rare cards to keep the game fun without spending a lot.

Magic: The Gathering is flexible; whether you’re playing casually with friends or aiming to compete in tournaments, there’s something for everyone. You can start simple with pre-made decks and gradually work your way up by trading cards and buying more packs as you get into it!
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: What are prions and are they a big deal ? My AP Biology teacher mentioned them alongside viruses but he did n't say much else beyond that they are n't viruses and they deform protein structure . Please explain like I'm five. Like viruses , they are ( groups of ) molecules that reproduce without metabolism . Unlike any other self - replicating system , prions are proteins that have a unique structure . One part of how a protein functions is the amino acid sequence that makes up the primary structure , but the other part is how the proteins folds , either by itself or with the help of other folder - helper proteins . Prions have the same amino acid sequence as their properly folded brethren , but they are folded differently , and they make a chain reaction by folding their brethren to be like them . Cruetzfeld - Jakob disease in humans , Mad Cow disease in cows , and chronic wasting disease in deer , are all prion diseases that affect neuronal proteins .
data.label: human

data.text:
Prions are quite intriguing, but let's break it down simply. Imagine they're a bit like viruses, but not the same at all. Your AP Biology teacher mentioned them because, just like viruses, they can multiply without needing to eat or breathe. However, what makes prions unique is that they're special types of proteins—tiny building blocks in our bodies.

Proteins work by folding into specific shapes, which helps them do their jobs. This shape comes from a sequence of amino acids and how these proteins twist and turn on themselves or with the help of other helper molecules. Prions are tricky because they have the same amino acid sequence as normal proteins but fold in an unusual way. They can cause a domino effect, making other similar proteins misfold into their wrong shape.

These prion diseases include things like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans and Mad Cow disease in cows, along with chronic wasting disease in deer. They all mess up the normal proteins in nerve cells (neurons). So yes, they can be quite a big deal because of how they disrupt normal protein functions.

data.text:
Prions are fascinating subjects worth exploring. Let's simplify them for better understanding. Consider prions as somewhat similar to viruses, yet distinctly different. Your AP Biology teacher brought them up because, like viruses, they have the ability to replicate without consuming food or air. However, what sets prions apart is that they belong to a unique category of proteins—fundamental components in our bodies.

Proteins typically assume specific structures that enable their functions, with this structure deriving from an amino acid sequence and how these proteins coil or interact with other molecules for assistance. Prions are particularly deceptive because they share the same amino acid sequence as regular proteins but fold in an atypical manner. They can initiate a chain reaction, causing other similar proteins to misfold incorrectly.

These prion-related illnesses include conditions such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, Mad Cow disease in cows, and chronic wasting disease in deer. All of these diseases interfere with the normal functioning of proteins within nerve cells (neurons). Indeed, they can be quite significant due to their capacity to disturb regular protein activities.

As someone who suffers from severe depression I can tell you mine is both physical and psychological . I know in my heart that no matter what circumstances I could ever be subjected to would never change that or get rid of it , it would be more of a genetics thing I suppose . Lately I tried to explain it to a friend and the only thing I can really use as an analogy for me are paper towels . Some are produced cheap and are shit , they tear and do n't soak up shit . These paper towels are still trying to be good but poor genes have them already behind a better crafted towel . Now let 's pretend we have two hammocks with one being designed using the shitty paper towel and one using the really strong and absorbent towel . If you consider each one of life 's problems and also just poor genes as a marble and you were to drop a marble into the hammocks they would eventually fall thru and you would be screwed . I view talking and medicine as a removal of a marble or two and at the end of the day I suppose each person develops ways of removing marbles but the marbles do n't stop coming . This whole life is just a flimsy , soaked towel and I lost my marbles .

data.text: Why do movie companies build sets rather than film on scene ? Seems like any location will do and seems like it 's cheaper to find an existing location rather than building their own . But I 'm open to being wrong . Please explain like I'm five. Most of the time , any location wo nt do . They want a specific look , so they build a set to fit that look . Or there s nothing like it nearby , and it 's cheaper than paying everyone to live somewhere else for the length of the shoot . Also , many public places simply ca n't be close off that long . If you 're filming a movie over the course of a year , you might be able to shut down an area for a few days of shooting , but if you need that space often you 're not going to be able to shut down a park or roads every few days . Also , if you 're filming in a public area it 's hard to stop the public from wandering in or watching from as close as possible . also , they can build the set without certain walls or in certain ways so camera angles that are n't possible in real places you can suddenly do . And if you have to destroy something ..... or have something loud and noisy or distracting ...

data.text:
Why do movie companies choose to construct sets instead of filming on location? It might seem like it's easier and cheaper to use an existing place, but there are reasons why they often build their own settings. Let me explain it simply:

Sometimes, any real-world location won't work because the filmmakers want a very specific look or setting that doesn't exist nearby. Building a set allows them to create exactly what they need.

Additionally, many public places can't be closed off for long periods. Filming might only allow a park or road to be shut down for a few days at a time, but if a film needs access frequently, it's impractical.

If filming occurs in a busy public area, people often wander into the scene or gather closely to watch, which can disrupt filming. Sets help avoid this by controlling who has access.

Also, sets can be constructed with flexible designs, such as missing walls or special angles, allowing filmmakers to capture shots that aren't possible in real places.

Lastly, on a set, they have more control over potential issues like loud noises or needing to destroy something without disturbing actual locations.

data.text: What is a " Tor exit node " or " Tor node " What is a " Tor exit node " or " Tor node " ? Please explain like I'm five. I 'm going to go off the assumption that you do n't know what tor is , if you do then feel free to skip the next paragraph . The entire idea behind tor is that by bouncing your information through different relay points , each of which is secured and the data transfers between them are encrypted , thus making your communications much harder to trace back to you . If I turn on my computer and use a regular browser , lets say Firefox , my computer requests that a specific bit of information from , lets say , reddit . My request is sent from my computer , to my ISP 's servers , to the servers of the website and then takes the little bit of information , lets say a specific webpage , and then does that same process in reverse . Taking the information from the servers of the website to the ISP 's servers and then back to my computer . Tor complicates this process by , rather then doing a straight line of data from computer to ISP to site , first encrypting all the communication and then secondly bouncing that signal / request for data around before submitting the request for information . This has the effect of making you appear like your in another place and posses a different IP address then you actually do . Simply put , a Tor node is one of the small parts of the jump that obfuscates your physical location and IP address by bouncing your information . An exit node is a tor node that serves as the ' exit ' point from the tor network and sends the actual request for information from the site . Hopefully that clears this up , if you have anymore questions just ask . :)
data.label: human

data.text:
Certainly! Here's a rephrased version:

A "Tor exit node" or simply a "Tor node" is part of something called Tor, which helps keep your online activities private. If you're not familiar with what Tor does, let me explain: Imagine sending a letter but instead of going straight to the recipient, it takes a zigzag path through several friends' houses before reaching its destination. That way, no one can easily trace where it started or who sent it.

Normally, if you use a web browser like Firefox on your computer to visit a website like Reddit, your request goes in a straight line from your computer to the internet service provider (ISP), then to the website's servers, and back again. This makes it relatively easy for others to see where the request came from because they can trace that direct path.

Tor changes this by encrypting your data and sending it through multiple nodes before reaching its final destination. Each node only knows about the previous and next hop in the journey, not the entire route or what you're doing online. This makes it look like your internet traffic is coming from somewhere else, hiding both where you are and your IP address.

In simple terms, a Tor node is one of these middle points that help disguise your location by making your data bounce around. An exit node is the last stop in this network path before your request reaches the actual website; it's like the point where the letter leaves your friends' houses to finally reach its recipient. 

If you have any more questions, feel free to ask! 😊
data.label: qwen_1

This way, it's difficult for anyone to trace where the letter originated or who sent it.

Typically, when using a web browser like Firefox on your computer to visit a site such as Reddit, your request travels in a straight line from your device to your internet service provider (ISP), then to the website’s servers, and back. data.text: How does DRM work ? Digital Rights Management . The wikipedia page goes off in many directions . First hit my radar with the Xbox One stuff . How does DRM work and why is it so controversial ? Thank you ! Please explain like I'm five. The reason wikipedia goes off in many directions is because it 's a generic term , it does n't describe any single technique . It 's just attempting to get people to pay you for their thing , preventing them from pirating it . It 's controversial because a lot of DRM implementations tend to be very inconvenient for the legit customers , whereas the people that would pirate your product will likely be able to do it anyway , and because their copy is cracked , they do n't see the downside of the restrictive DRM . It literally only hurts the paying customers , which in turn forces more people to pirate . Nobody wins .
data.label: human

data.text:
What is DRM, or Digital Rights Management? The Wikipedia page discusses various aspects. I first noticed it with Xbox One discussions. How does DRM work, and why is it controversial? Let me explain simply.

DRM is a broad term that doesn't refer to one specific method but generally aims to ensure people pay for digital content rather than pirate it. This can be annoying because many DRM systems make things difficult for honest customers who have paid. Meanwhile, those inclined to pirate might still find ways around it and won't face the same inconveniences. Essentially, these restrictions often only bother paying users, which ironically can lead to more piracy as a result. In this scenario, nobody really benefits.

The reason Wikipedia has many directions is that DRM encompasses various strategies rather than one single approach. It's meant to protect content by preventing unauthorized distribution but often ends up frustrating legitimate buyers instead.

What exactly is DRM, or Digital Rights Management? The Wikipedia page explores its numerous facets. I first came across this concept during discussions about the Xbox One. How does DRM operate, and why does it spark controversy? Let me break it down simply.

DRM is an overarching term that doesn't describe a single technique but generally aims to ensure that consumers pay for digital content rather than pirating it. This can be frustrating because many DRM systems complicate things for honest customers who have already paid. Meanwhile, those inclined to pirate might still find ways around these barriers and won't face the same difficulties. In essence, these restrictions often only inconvenience paying users, which ironically may drive more people toward piracy as a result. Ultimately, this situation leaves no one truly benefiting.

The reason Wikipedia covers so many angles is that DRM includes various strategies instead of just one uniform approach. Its purpose is to safeguard content by preventing unauthorized sharing but frequently ends up irritating legitimate buyers in the process.

When you're moving between deep sleep and the lighter stage of sleep where it's easier to wake up, something called sleep paralysis happens. This keeps us from acting out our dreams. Sometimes, when you're about to wake up and your brain accidentally hits the "sleep paralysis" switch again, it can feel really strange. The sudden tension in your body might make you think you’re falling while your mind is still a bit confused. When you transition between deep sleep and the lighter stage where it's easier to wake up, something known as sleep paralysis occurs. This mechanism prevents us from physically acting out our dreams. Occasionally, just before waking up, your brain might accidentally trigger sleep paralysis again, leading to an unusual sensation. The sudden tension in your body can give you the impression that you’re falling while your mind is still a bit disoriented. It’s strong enough that it could feel like you’ve landed on the bed with a bounce—though really, your body has simply activated its safety mode by mistake.

data.text: Why the same products / brands have differents names in different countries ? for example : USA - Crest ; Europe - Blend - a - Med Feel free to give some more examples :) Please explain like I'm five. Sometimes it 's for legal reasons . For example , there was already a Burger King restaurant in Australia , so in order to avoid violating the other restaurant 's trademark , Burger King was re - branded as Hungry Jack 's ( which it 's still called in Australia today ) . Other times the name is changed because it historical / cultural meaning of the original name is lost across borders . For example , Harry Potter and the Philospher 's Stone was renamed Harry Potter and the Sorcerer 's Stone for US audiences because the mythology / story surrounding the Philospher 's Stone is not part of popular US culture / common knowledge , so the name lost it 's meaning in the US and Sorcerer 's Stone was seen to make more sense . Lastly , brand names are sometimes changed because the name may have a different meaning in another culture which ( potentially ) has a negative or inappropriate connotation . For example , the Honda Fit was originally going to be called the Honda Fitta until it was discovered that ' Fitta ' roughly translates to ' pussy ' in many Nordic languages . Another example is Church 's Chicken which has been re - branded as Texas Chicken in other parts of the world where ' Church ' is assumed to have a religious connection ( as opposed to just being a person 's name ) .

data.text:
Why do products or brands often have different names in various countries? For instance, in the USA, it's Crest, but in Europe, it's Blend-a-Med. Here are some examples and explanations:

1. **Legal Reasons**: Sometimes, the original brand name is already taken by another company in a country. For example, Burger King had to change its name to Hungry Jack's in Australia because there was already a Burger King restaurant there.

2. **Cultural Differences**: The meaning of a product’s name might not be understood everywhere due to cultural differences. Like "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" being renamed to "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in the US, since people there didn't know about the Philosopher's Stone from mythology.

3. **Language Issues**: Sometimes, a brand name might have an unintended meaning in another language that could be awkward or offensive. For instance, Honda originally named their car the Fitta, but they changed it because "fitta" means something rude in some Nordic languages. Also, Church’s Chicken became Texas Chicken elsewhere since “Church” might imply religion instead of being just a name.

So, brands often change names to avoid confusion, legal issues, or cultural misunderstandings!
