data.text:
In computer science, "Computation time" refers to the concept of time complexity, which indicates how much computer time an algorithm requires to run. Time complexity is often assessed by tallying the number of basic operations executed by the algorithm, assuming each operation takes a consistent duration. Consequently, the total execution time and the count of these fundamental operations are connected through a constant factor.

Since an algorithm's runtime can vary with different inputs of identical size, it is typical to consider its worst-case time complexity—the longest amount of time necessary for inputs of that size. Less frequently discussed but sometimes explicitly mentioned is average-case complexity, representing the mean execution time across all possible inputs of a particular size (given there are only a finite number of such inputs). In both scenarios, time complexity is generally articulated as a function of input size.

The function describing this complexity can be challenging to calculate precisely and becomes less significant for small inputs. Thus, attention often shifts to the algorithm's asymptotic behavior as input sizes grow. This leads to expressing time complexity using big O notation, such as \(O(n)\), \(O(n \log n)\), \(O(n^\alpha)\), \(O(2^n)\), and so on, where \(n\) represents the number of bits required to represent the input.

Algorithms are categorized based on the functions appearing in their big O notation. For instance, an algorithm with a time complexity of \(O(n)\) is considered linear-time, while one with a complexity of \(O(n^\alpha)\), for some constant \(\alpha > 1\), is classified as polynomial-time.

While less frequently highlighted, average-case complexity, which denotes the average execution time over all possible inputs of a specific size (assuming there are only finitely many such inputs), can also be considered. Algorithms are classified based on the functions used in their big O notation. For example, an algorithm with a time complexity of \(O(n)\) is termed linear-time, while one with a complexity of \(O(n^\alpha)\), for some constant \(\alpha > 1\), falls into the polynomial-time category.

data.text: Please explain what is "Pruning (algorithm)" Pruning is a data compression technique in machine learning and search algorithms that reduces the size of decision trees by removing sections of the tree that are non-critical and redundant to classify instances. Pruning reduces the complexity of the final classifier, and hence improves predictive accuracy by the reduction of overfitting.One of the questions that arises in a decision tree algorithm is the optimal size of the final tree.  A tree that is too large risks overfitting the training data and poorly generalizing to new samples.  A small tree might not capture important structural information about the sample space.  However, it is hard to tell when a tree algorithm should stop because it is impossible to tell if the addition of a single extra node will dramatically decrease error.  This problem is known as the horizon effect.  A common strategy is to grow the tree until each node contains a small number of instances then use pruning to remove nodes that do not provide additional information.Pruning should reduce the size of a learning tree without reducing predictive accuracy as measured by a cross-validation set.  There are many techniques for tree pruning that differ in the measurement that is used to optimize performance.
data.label: human

data.text:
Certainly! Here's the rephrased paragraph:

Pruning (algorithm) refers to a data compression method utilized in machine learning and search algorithms, which aims to decrease the size of decision trees by eliminating non-essential and redundant sections crucial for classifying instances. This process not only simplifies the final classifier but also enhances predictive accuracy by mitigating overfitting.

A common challenge in decision tree algorithms is determining the optimal size of the finished tree. An overly large tree may lead to overfitting the training data, resulting in poor generalization to new samples, whereas a small tree might overlook important structural details within the sample space. Identifying when to halt further growth of the tree is difficult due to the horizon effect, which makes it uncertain whether adding an additional node will significantly reduce error.

A typical approach involves expanding the tree until each node contains only a few instances, followed by pruning to remove nodes that do not contribute additional information.

The goal of pruning should be to decrease the learning tree's size without compromising its predictive accuracy, as assessed using a cross-validation set. Various techniques for tree pruning exist, each optimizing performance based on different metrics.

data.text: Please explain what is "Hill climbing" In numerical analysis, hill climbing is a mathematical optimization technique which belongs to the family of local search. It is an iterative algorithm that starts with an arbitrary solution to a problem, then attempts to find a better solution by making an incremental change to the solution. If the change produces a better solution, another incremental change is made to the new solution, and so on until no further improvements can be found.For example, hill climbing can be applied to the travelling salesman problem. It is easy to find an initial solution that visits all the cities but will likely be very poor compared to the optimal solution. The algorithm starts with such a solution and makes small improvements to it, such as switching the order in which two cities are visited. Eventually, a much shorter route is likely to be obtained.Hill climbing finds optimal solutions for convex problems – for other problems it will find only local optima (solutions that cannot be improved upon by any neighboring configurations), which are not necessarily the best possible solution (the global optimum) out of all possible solutions (the search space). Examples of algorithms that solve convex problems by hill-climbing include the simplex algorithm for linear programming and binary search.: 253  To attempt to avoid getting stuck in local optima, one could use restarts (i.e. repeated local search), or more complex schemes based on iterations (like iterated local search), or on memory (like reactive search optimization and tabu search), or on memory-less stochastic modifications (like simulated annealing).The relative simplicity of the algorithm makes it a popular first choice amongst optimizing algorithms. It is used widely in artificial intelligence, for reaching a goal state from a starting node. Different choices for next nodes and starting nodes are used in related algorithms. Although more advanced algorithms such as simulated annealing or tabu search may give better results, in some situations hill climbing works just as well. Hill climbing can often produce a better result than other algorithms when the amount of time available to perform a search is limited, such as with real-time systems, so long as a small number of increments typically converges on a good solution (the optimal solution or a close approximation). At the other extreme, bubble sort can be viewed as a hill climbing algorithm (every adjacent element exchange decreases the number of disordered element pairs), yet this approach is far from efficient for even modest N, as the number of exchanges required grows quadratically. Hill climbing is an anytime algorithm: it can return a valid solution even if it's interrupted at any time before it ends.

data.text:
Hill climbing in numerical analysis refers to a mathematical optimization method within the local search family. This iterative process begins with an arbitrary problem solution, then seeks an improved solution through incremental modifications. If these changes yield better results, further adjustments are made until no enhancements can be found.

For instance, hill climbing can address the travelling salesman problem by starting with a basic route that visits all cities but is likely suboptimal. The algorithm incrementally refines this route, such as altering the sequence of city visits, ultimately leading to a shorter path.

Hill climbing effectively finds optimal solutions for convex problems; however, for other types, it may only identify local optima—solutions that cannot be improved by nearby configurations but are not necessarily the global optimum. The simplex algorithm for linear programming and binary search are examples of algorithms solving convex issues through hill climbing.

To mitigate getting stuck in local optima, strategies such as restarts (repeated local searches), iterations (like iterated local search), memory-based approaches (such as reactive search optimization and tabu search), or stochastic modifications without memory (like simulated annealing) can be employed.

Due to its simplicity, hill climbing is often a preferred initial choice among optimizing algorithms. It's widely used in artificial intelligence for achieving a goal state from a starting node, with variations in subsequent and initial nodes leading to related algorithms. While more advanced methods like simulated annealing or tabu search may yield superior outcomes, hill climbing can be equally effective under certain conditions.

Hill climbing frequently delivers better results than other algorithms when time constraints exist, such as in real-time systems, provided a few iterations lead to an optimal or near-optimal solution. Conversely, while bubble sort functions similarly by reducing disordered element pairs with each adjacent swap, it is inefficient for larger datasets due to the quadratic growth of necessary exchanges.

As an anytime algorithm, hill climbing can return a valid solution if interrupted at any point before completion.

data.text: Please explain what is "Random optimization" Random optimization (RO) is a family of numerical optimization methods that do not require the gradient of the problem to be optimized and RO can hence be used on functions that are not continuous or differentiable. Such optimization methods are also known as direct-search, derivative-free, or black-box methods.The name random optimization is attributed to Matyas  who made an early presentation of RO along with basic mathematical analysis. RO works by iteratively moving to better positions in the search-space which are sampled using e.g. a normal distribution surrounding the current position.

data.text: Please explain what is "Beam search" In computer science, beam search is a heuristic search algorithm that explores a graph by expanding the most promising node in a limited set. Beam search is an optimization of best-first search that reduces its memory requirements. Best-first search is a graph search which orders all partial solutions (states) according to some heuristic. But in beam search, only a predetermined number of best partial solutions are kept as candidates. It is thus a greedy algorithm.The term "beam search" was coined by Raj Reddy of Carnegie Mellon University in 1977.

data.text: Please explain what is "Simulated annealing" Simulated annealing (SA) is a probabilistic technique for approximating the global optimum of a given function. Specifically, it is a metaheuristic to approximate global optimization in a large search space for an optimization problem. It is often used when the search space is discrete (for example the traveling salesman problem, the boolean satisfiability problem, protein structure prediction, and job-shop scheduling). For problems where finding an approximate global optimum is more important than finding a precise local optimum in a fixed amount of time, simulated annealing may be preferable to exact algorithms such as gradient descent or branch and bound.The name of the algorithm comes from annealing in metallurgy, a technique involving heating and controlled cooling of a material to alter its physical properties. Both are attributes of the material that depend on their thermodynamic free energy. Heating and cooling the material affects both the temperature and the thermodynamic free energy or Gibbs energy.Simulated annealing can be used for very hard computational optimization problems where exact algorithms fail; even though it usually achieves an approximate solution to the global minimum, it could be enough for many practical problems.The problems solved by SA are currently formulated by an objective function of many variables, subject to several constraints. In practice, the constraint can be penalized as part of the objective function.Similar techniques have been independently introduced on several occasions, including Pincus (1970), Khachaturyan et al (1979, 1981), Kirkpatrick, Gelatt and Vecchi (1983), and Cerny (1985). In 1983, this approach was used by Kirkpatrick, Gelatt Jr., Vecchi, for a solution of the traveling salesman problem. They also proposed its current name, simulated annealing.This notion of slow cooling implemented in the simulated annealing algorithm is interpreted as a slow decrease in the probability of accepting worse solutions as the solution space is explored. Accepting worse solutions allows for a more extensive search for the global optimal solution. In general, simulated annealing algorithms work as follows. The temperature progressively decreases from an initial positive value to zero. At each time step, the algorithm randomly selects a solution close to the current one, measures its quality, and moves to it according to the temperature-dependent probabilities of selecting better or worse solutions, which during the search respectively remain at 1 (or positive) and decrease toward zero.The simulation can be performed either by a solution of kinetic equations for density functions or by using the stochastic sampling method. The method is an adaptation of the Metropolis–Hastings algorithm, a Monte Carlo method to generate sample states of a thermodynamic system, published by N. Metropolis et al. in 1953.

data.text:
Please describe what "Simulated Annealing" entails. Simulated annealing (SA) is a probabilistic approach for finding an approximate global optimum of a given function. It serves as a metaheuristic method to tackle global optimization challenges within extensive search spaces. This technique is particularly useful in discrete search space problems, such as the traveling salesman problem, boolean satisfiability problem, protein structure prediction, and job-shop scheduling. For scenarios where identifying an approximate global optimum outweighs locating a precise local optimum within a set timeframe, simulated annealing may be more advantageous than exact methods like gradient descent or branch-and-bound.

The algorithm derives its name from annealing in metallurgy, which involves heating and controlled cooling of materials to change their physical properties, both influenced by thermodynamic free energy. This process parallels how simulated annealing impacts computational solutions for difficult optimization problems where precise algorithms may not be feasible; it often delivers an approximate global minimum, sufficient for many practical applications.

Problems addressed with SA are structured through an objective function involving multiple variables and constraints. Typically, these constraints can be integrated into the objective function as penalties. This technique has been independently developed several times, including by Pincus (1970), Khachaturyan et al. (1979, 1981), Kirkpatrick, Gelatt, and Vecchi (1983), and Cerny (1985). In 1983, it was applied to the traveling salesman problem by Kirkpatrick, Gelatt Jr., and Vecchi, who also coined its current name.

Simulated annealing incorporates a gradual cooling strategy, which is interpreted as slowly reducing the probability of accepting inferior solutions while exploring the solution space. This acceptance allows for broader exploration towards identifying the global optimal solution. Typically, SA algorithms decrease temperature from an initial positive value to zero progressively. At each step, the algorithm randomly chooses a nearby solution, evaluates its quality, and moves according to probabilities that depend on the current temperature, with higher chances for better solutions (remaining at 1 or above) and lower probabilities for worse ones, which approach zero over time.

The simulation can be executed through solving kinetic equations for density functions or by using stochastic sampling methods. This method is an adaptation of the Metropolis–Hastings algorithm, a Monte Carlo technique to generate sample states of thermodynamic systems introduced by N. Metropolis et al. in 1953.

Please explain what "Simulated Annealing" involves. Simulated annealing (SA) is a probabilistic technique used to find an approximate global optimum for a specified function. It functions as a metaheuristic approach to address global optimization issues within large search spaces. This method is particularly beneficial in discrete search space problems, such as the traveling salesman problem, boolean satisfiability problem, protein structure prediction, and job-shop scheduling. In situations where finding an approximate global optimum is more critical than identifying a precise local optimum within a given timeframe, simulated annealing may prove to be more effective than exact methods like gradient descent or branch-and-bound.

The algorithm's name is inspired by the metallurgical process of annealing, which involves heating and controlled cooling of materials to alter their physical properties, both influenced by thermodynamic free energy. This analogy reflects how simulated annealing affects computational solutions for complex optimization problems where precise algorithms might not be viable; it often produces an approximate global minimum that suffices for many practical purposes.

Problems tackled with SA are defined through an objective function with multiple variables and constraints. Typically, these constraints can be incorporated into the objective function as penalties. This method has been independently developed several times by researchers such as Pincus (1970), Khachaturyan et al. (1979, 1981), Kirkpatrick, Gelatt, and Vecchi (1983), and Cerny (1985). In 1983, it was applied to the traveling salesman problem by Kirkpatrick, Gelatt Jr., and Vecchi, who also named it as such.

Simulated annealing employs a gradual cooling approach, interpreted as slowly reducing the likelihood of accepting inferior solutions while exploring the solution space. This acceptance enables a more extensive exploration in pursuit of the global optimal solution. Typically, SA algorithms gradually reduce the temperature from an initial positive value to zero. At each stage, the algorithm randomly selects a nearby solution, assesses its quality, and proceeds based on probabilities that depend on the current temperature; better solutions have higher chances (always 1 or greater), while worse ones have decreasing probabilities, approaching zero over time.

The simulation can be carried out by solving kinetic equations for density functions or through stochastic sampling methods. This method is a variation of the Metropolis–Hastings algorithm, a Monte Carlo technique to generate sample states of thermodynamic systems introduced by N. Metropolis et al. in 1953.
